text: We have seen an increase in attacks that leverage malicious LNK files that use legitimate apps—like PowerShell—to download malware or other malicious files.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: we have seen an increase in attacks that leverage malicious LNK files that use legitimate apps—like PowerShell—to download malware or other malicious files.

text:
By: Benson Sy
May 25, 2017
Read time: 5 min (1251 words)
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: Benson SyMay 25, 2017Read time: 5 min (1251 words) read the rest of the story on cnn ireport.

text: Update as of May 30, 2017, 5:00 AM CDT to update the date referencing Trojan downloaders that used .zip files within .zip files from "2016" to "2017".
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: update as of May 30, 2017, 5:00 AM CDT to update the date referencing Trojan downloaders.zip files from "2016" to "2017"

text: PowerShell is a versatile command-line and shell scripting language from Microsoft that can integrate and interact with a wide array of technologies. It runs discreetly in the background, and can be used to obtain system information without an executable file. All told, it makes an attractive tool for threat actors. There were a few notable instances where cybercriminals abused PowerShell: in March 2016 with the PowerWare ransomware, and in a new Fareit malware variant in April 2016. Because this seemed to be an upward trend, security administrators became more familiar with how to prevent PowerShell scripts from doing any damage.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: it runs discreetly in the background, and can be used to obtain system information without an executable file. security administrators became more familiar with how to prevent PowerShell scripts from doing any damage.

text: However, cybercriminals are staying ahead of the curve by using alternative means of executing PowerShell script—Windows LNK (LNK) extensions. LNK files are usually seen by users as shortcuts, and used in places like the Desktop and Start Menu. LNK was actually already used as an attack vector as early as 2013. And in early 2017, we noted how Trojan downloaders used a .zip within a .zip to disguise a LNK file attachment that led to the Locky ransomware.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: cybercriminals are using alternative means of executing Windows LNK (LNK) extensions. they are usually seen by users as shortcuts, and used in places like the Desktop and Start Menu.

text: Now, we’re seeing an increase in attacks that leverage malicious LNK files that use legitimate apps—like PowerShell—to download malware or other malicious files. To illustrate how the trend of using LNK files is rising, note how one single LNK malware (identified by Trend Micro as LNK_DLOADR.*) has had a significant jump in detections since January 2017. The steep rise shows how popular this method is becoming:
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: one single malware (identified by Trend Micro as LNK_DLOADR.*) has had a significant jump in detections since January 2017.

text: In October 2016 we saw attackers using the combination of LNK, PowerShell, and the BKDR_ChChes malware in targeted attacks against Japanese government agencies and academics. The attack used a fake .jpg extension to camouflage the malicious PowerShell file.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: attackers used the combination of LNK, PowerShell and the BKDR_ChChes malware in targeted attacks against government agencies and academics.

text: Figure 2. Attack used to compromise Japanese targets in October 2016
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: attack used to compromise targets in japan in October 2016. the attack was used in a similar attack in the u.s.

text: In January 2017 we spotted the group APT10 (also called MenuPass, POTASSIUM, Stone Panda, Red Apollo, and CVNX) using a similar attack for a wide-spread spear phishing campaign. In this version, the LNK file executes CMD.exe, which in turn downloads a fake .jpg file hiding the malicious PowerShell script.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: in this version, the LNK file executes CMD.exe, which in turn downloads a fake.jpg file hiding the malicious PowerShell script.

text: The group has continued to evolve their cyberespionage activities, and in April 2017 they used a similar strategy to also download BKDR_ChChes, which is a popular malware used in targeted attacks.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: the group has continued to evolve their cyberespionage activities. in April 2017 they used a similar strategy to also download BKDR_ChChes, the popular malware used in targeted attacks.

text: We identified one campaign, likely still ongoing, that has a new and complicated LNK strategy. These attackers seem to be using several layers of command line, built-in, Windows tools. They send a phishing email with lures that push the victim to “double click for content”, typically a DOCX or RTF file embedded with a malicious LNK. Instead of directly executing PowerShell, the LNK file will execute MSHTA.exe (a file used for opening HTML applications), which executes a Javascript or VBScript code that in turn downloads and executes the PowerShell script. The PowerShell then executes a reverse shell (like Metasploit or Cobalt Strike) to complete the compromise.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: attackers seem to be using several layers of command line, built-in, Windows tools. they send a phishing email with lures that push the victim to "double click for content" instead of directly executing PowerShell, the LNK file will execute MSHTA.exe (a file used for opening HTML applications)

text: Last month we identified another spear phishing campaign also using a combination of LNK and PowerShell. Unfortunately, the Command and Control (C&C) server where the main payload was stored is no longer accessible.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: last month we identified another spear phishing campaign using a combination of LNK and PowerShell. the command and control server where the main payload was stored is no longer accessible.

text: Their strategy seems to have fewer layers: the LNK file is embedded in a document file and if a user double clicks to open the message, it executes a PowerShell file (or a similar Windows command line tool) to download another script. The other script then downloads the main payload.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: if an user double clicks to open the message, it executes a PowerShell file to download another script. the other script then downloads the main payload.

text: We believe this specific attack may be politically motivated due to the economic and controversial subject of the decoy document. However, a full analysis is tricky because the trail ends when one of the C&C servers dies. Without the full picture, it is difficult to associate this type of attack to known campaigns.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: we believe this specific attack may be politically motivated due to the economic and controversial subject of the decoy document. without the full picture, it is difficult to associate this type of attack to known campaigns.

text: In many cases, these malicious LNK files can reveal valuable information about the attacker’s development environment. To help get this information, a quick analysis is possible by viewing the properties of the file.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: in many cases, these malicious LNK files can reveal valuable information about the attacker’s development environment. a quick analysis is possible by viewing the properties of the file.

text: However, we are encountering cases where the command line argument is so long that it is no longer fully visible in the Properties > Shortcut window. When viewed, only the target application (CMD.exe, MSHTA.exe, and other non-malicious command line applications) is seen.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: the command line argument is so long that it is no longer fully visible in the Properties > Shortcut window. when viewed, only the target application (CMD.exe, and other non-malicious command lines) is seen.

text: Our tests revealed that the maximum length for Shortcut > Properties > Target is only 260 characters. Anything longer than that will not be visible. However, the maximum length for a command line argument is 4096 characters.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: our tests revealed that the maximum length for Shortcut > Properties > Target is only 260 characters. Anything longer than that will not be visible.

text: The attacker actually pads several spaces or newline characters before the malicious argument. Using a parser tool reveals that it is much longer (figure 6), though it still works normally:
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: the attacker actually pads several spaces or newline characters before the malicious argument. a parser tool reveals that it is much longer (figure 6).

text: Attackers take advantage of this to try and disguise or hide the malicious portion of the code. This padding strategy may prevent a quick analysis of a LNK file, but any LNK parser can still extract the arguments without any problem.
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: attackers try to disguise or hide the malicious portion of the code. any LNK parser can still extract the arguments without any problem.

text: Malware developers continue to upgrade their tools and look for different ways to deliver their malicious payloads. Leveraging these LNK files is another strategy, but there are ways to prevent and mitigate these threats:
source: How Attackers are Using LNK Files to Download Malware.html
summary: malware developers continue to upgrade their tools and look for different ways to deliver their malicious payloads. leveraging these LNK files is another strategy, but there are way to prevent and mitigate these threats.

text:
Quasar [1] is an open source RAT (Remote Administration Tool) with a variety of functions. This is easy to use and therefore exploited by several APT actors. JPCERT/CC has confirmed that a group called APT10 used this tool in some targeted attacks against Japanese organisations.
As Quasar’s source code is publicly available, there are many variants of this RAT seen in the wild (referred to as “Quasar Family” hereafter). Some of them have been used in attacks against Japanese organisations, and they are seen as a threat as well as Quasar itself.
This article introduces the details of Quasar and Quasar Family.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: JPCERT/CC has confirmed that a group called APT10 used this tool in some targeted attacks against Japanese organisations. there are many variants of this RAT seen in the wild (referred to as “Quasar Family” hereafter)

text: Quasar offers many functions which are intended for purposes such as device management, support operation and employee monitoring. Figure 1 describes Quasar’s functions and its supported environment as specified on GitHub.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: Quasar offers many functions which are intended for purposes such as device management, support operation and employee monitoring. figure 1 describes the functions and its supported environment as specified on GitHub.

text: This tool was called “xRAT” at the time of its initial release, however, it was renamed as “Quasar” in August 2015. The latest version is v1.4, released in June 2020.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: the tool was called “xRAT” at the time of its initial release. it was renamed “Quasar” in august 2015.

text: As v1.3 and the earlier are still used in recent attacks, this article explains the functions of both v1.3 and v1.4.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: as v1.3 and the earlier are still used in recent attacks. this article explains the functions of both the previous and previous versions.

text:
Quasar v1.3 uses its custom protocol which combines AES and QuickLZ. In v1.4, however, Protocol Buffer (developed by Google) is used for data serialisation instead. In addition, the entire communication is encrypted with TLS1.2.
Figure 3 shows the comparison of the communication format in v1.3 and v1.4.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: Quasar v1.3 uses its custom protocol which combines AES and QuickLZ. the entire communication is encrypted with TLS1.2.

text:
In v1.3, once a client connects to a server, authentication is performed. After that, the main body of data including the commands are exchanged. On the other hand, the authentication is replaced by a TLS handshake in v1.4, and the data exchange begins after that.
Figure 4 illustrates Quasar’s communication flow between a client and a server.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: in v1.3, once client connects to a server, authentication is performed. after that, the main body of data including the commands are exchanged.

text: Quasar possesses its configuration in itself. It is encrypted by the combination of AES and BASE64 encoding. It is decrypted with the value specified in “ENCRYPTIONKEY” in the configuration when executed.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: Quasar is encrypted by combination of AES and BASE64 encoding. it is decrypted with the value specified in "ENCRYPTIONKEY"

text: In v1.3, command sets are defined for “typeof” calls. Figure 7 shows some examples of commands defined in Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: in v1.3, command sets are defined for "typeof" calls. figure 7 shows some examples of commands defined in Quasar.

text: Table 2 is the list of Quasar Family derived from Quasar which JPCERT/CC confirmed.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: table 2 is the list of family derived from Quasar which was confirmed by JPCERT/CC. the family is based on a family of people from the u.s.

text: * “Clone” in the category refers to variants which uses the entire source code of Quasar with some functions added or modified. “Partially copied” refers to variants created as a new RAT using parts of the original source code.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: "Clone" in the category refers to variants which uses the entire source code of Quasar with some functions added or modified.

text: Figure 8 shows the comparison of commands embedded in XPCTRA and Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: figures 8 and 8 show the comparison of commands embedded in XPCTRA and Quasar. xptra and qctra are the same commands.

text:
In the comparison above, it is clear that commands in XPCTRA are mostly identical to those in Quasar.
Figure 9 shows the comparison of the salt value in AsyncRAT and Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: it is clear that commands in XPCTRA are mostly identical to those in Quasar. Figure 9 shows the comparison of the salt value in AsyncRAT and.

text:
The salt value in AsyncRAT is identical to that in Quasar.
As Quasar Family applies some parts of the source code of Quasar, its configuration and communication protocol are also identical. In some cases, some functions are customised, and as a result, some new configuration and commands are added.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: the salt value in AsyncRAT is identical to that in Quasar. some functions are customised, and as a result, some new commands are added.

text: Quasar has been used in many attack campaigns. Table 3 lists the differences of Quasar used by each attack group.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: Quasar has been used in many attack campaigns. Table 3 lists the differences between each attack group and a group of attackers.

text: The original Quasar with the default configuration value was used in most cases. Figure 10 shows an example configuration of Quasar used by APT 33.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: the original Quasar with the default configuration value was used in most cases. Figure 10 shows an example configuration used by APT 33.

text: In most parts, the default values of the builder generating Quasar are used as is, except for STARTUPKEY. This way, attacker groups use the default values as per the original to avoid leaving any distinctive evidence.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: the default values of the builder generating Quasar are used as is, except for STARTUPKEY. attacker groups use them as per the original to avoid leaving any distinctive evidence.

text: In some cases, attackers customise Quasar. For example, APT 10 updated some features and used it in some attacks. The following sections will cover the details of this custom Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: in some cases, attackers customise Quasar. for example, APT 10 updated some features and used it in others attacks.

text: Quasar used by APT 10 (hereafter “custom Quasar”) has the following additional values in the configuration.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: Quasar used by APT 10 has the following additional values in the configuration. if you have any questions, please contact us for more information.

text: Figure 11 shows the comparison of configuration in the custom Quasar and the original Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: Figure 11 shows the comparison of configuration in the custom Quasar and the original. if you are looking for a specific configuration, click here for more information.

text:
In “PROXY”, a proxy server URL can be configured. This ensures that the custom Quasar is able to communicate with a C2 server even if the target’s environment uses proxy servers.
While the original Quasar uses CBC mode when encrypting configuration with AES, the custom Quasar uses CFB mode.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: the custom Quasar is able to communicate with a C2 server even if the target’s environment uses proxy servers.

text: There are some changes to the commands in the custom Quasar. Figure 13 shows the comparison of commands in the custom Quasar and the original Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: figure 13 shows the comparison of commands in the custom Quasar and the original. figures show the difference between the commands used in a custom and an original.

text:
In the custom Quasar, new commands DoPlugin and DoPluginResponse are added while some including keylogger are deleted.
With DoPlugin, new functions can be added by loading additional plugin modules. These new modules can be deleted with DoPluginResponse.
This change enables Quasar to dynamically extend its functions with commands while maintaining Quasar itself as simple as it can be. This suggests the attacker’s intention to avoid detection by anti-virus software.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: in the custom Quasar, new commands doPlugin and DoPluginResponse are added while some including keylogger are deleted.

text: The custom Quasar has a function to create error logs. The file path of the error logs is hardcoded in itself.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: the custom Quasar has a function to create error logs. the file path of the log is hardcoded in itself.

text: The encryption algorithms for communication with a C2 server also differs in the custom Quasar. While the original Quasar uses AES and QuickLZ, the custom Quasar also uses XOR encoding. Figure 15 shows the XOR encoding process added to the custom Quasar.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: the custom Quasar uses encryption algorithms for communication with a C2 server. it also uses XOR encoding.

text: For AES encryption, the custom Quasar uses CFB mode instead of CBC mode, as seen in the configuration. The encryption methods are as follows:
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: the custom Quasar uses CFB mode instead of CBC mode, as seen in the configuration. the encryption methods are as follows:

text: JPCERT/CC investigated the activities of Quasar Family C2 servers based on the characteristics discussed above. As of November 2020, 76 IP addresses running as C2 servers have been identified. Figure 16 shows the distribution of Quasar Family C2 servers which were revealed in this investigation.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: JPCERT/CC investigated the activities of Quasar Family C2 servers based on the characteristics discussed above. as of November 2020, 76 IP addresses have been identified.

text: Multiple C2 servers are still running in different countries, which indicates its activeness.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: multiple C2 servers are still running in different countries, which indicates its activeness. the server is currently operating in a number of countries.

text:
Besides Quasar, other open source RATs are being used in ongoing attack cases [7]. Attackers are taking advantage of these tools to make attribution difficult and reduce the cost for developing attack infrastructure. It is estimated that this attack trends may continue.
A tool to support Quasar analysis (compatible with Quasar v1.3 only) is available on GitHub. We hope you find it useful.
source: Attack Activities by Quasar Family - JPCERT_CC Eyes _ JPCERT Coordination Center official Blog.html
summary: besides Quasar, other open source RATs are being used in ongoing attack cases [7]. it is estimated that this attack trends may continue.

text: ChessMaster, a campaign targeting Japanese academe, technology enterprises, media outfits, managed service providers, and government agencies, employs malware-laden spear-phishing emails with decoy documents purporting to be legitimate.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: ChessMaster employs malware-laden spear-phishing emails with decoy documents purporting to be legitimate. the campaign targets Japanese academe, technology enterprises, media outfits, managed service providers, and government agencies.

text:
By: Benson Sy, Kawabata Kohei
July 27, 2017
Read time: 4 min (1144 words)
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: Benson Sy, Kawabata KoheiJuly 27, 2017Read time: 4 min (1144 words) read more.

text: From gathering intelligence, using the right social engineering lures, and exploiting vulnerabilities to laterally moving within the network, targeted attacks have multifarious tools at their disposal. And like in a game of chess, they are the set pieces that make up their modus operandi.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: targeted attacks have multifarious tools at their disposal, from gathering intelligence, using the right social engineering lures to laterally moving within the network. they are the set pieces that make up their modus operandi.

text: Take for instance the self-named ChessMaster, a campaign targeting Japanese academe, technology enterprises, media outfits, managed service providers, and government agencies. It employs various poisoned pawns in the form of malware-laden spear-phishing emails containing decoy documents. And beyond ChessMaster’s endgame and pawns, we also found red flags that allude to its links to APT 10, also known as menuPass, POTASSIUM, Stone Panda, Red Apollo, and CVNX.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: the self-named campaign targeted japanese academe, technology enterprises, media outfits, and government agencies. it employs various poisoned pawns in the form of malware-laden spear-phishing emails containing decoy documents. we also found red flags that allude to its links to menuPass, POTASSIUM, Stone Panda, Red Apollo and CVNX.

text: ChessMaster’s name is from pieces of chess/checkers/draughts we found in the resource section of the main backdoor they use against their targets: ChChes, which Trend Micro detects as BKDR_CHCHES.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: ChessMaster's name is from pieces of chess/checkers/draughts we found in the resource section of the main backdoor they use against their targets.

text: What makes the campaign unique is its arsenal of tools and techniques:
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: what makes the campaign unique is its arsenal of tools and techniques: tools, techniques, and tools. campaign is aimed at promoting a new campaign in the u.s.

text: APT 10/menuPass is a cyberespionage group whose specific campaign, Operation Cloud Hopper, attacked the intermediaries of their targets of interest—managed service providers (MSPs). Its notoriety stems from their prolific use of multifarious information-stealing backdoors and vulnerability exploits, along with the tenacity of its subterfuges, from spear-phishing emails to attack and infection chains. It also abused legitimate or open-source remote administration tools to steal data.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: APT 10/menuPass is a cyberespionage group whose specific campaign, Operation Cloud Hopper, attacked the intermediaries of their targets of interest—managed service providers (MSPs) its notoriety stems from their prolific use of multifarious information-stealing backdoors and vulnerability exploits. it also abused legitimate or open-source remote administration tools to steal data.

text: If that sounded familiar, it's because ChessMaster and APT 10 appear to be playing the same cyberespionage game. Here’s a further illustration:
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: if that sounds familiar, it's because ChessMaster and APT 10 appear to be playing the same cyberespionage game.

text: We first saw ChChes set its sights on an organization that’s long been a target of APT 10/menuPass. As we caught and delved into more ChChes samples in the wild, however, we also saw how they followed the same pattern—exclusive packers, mutual targets, overlapping C&C infrastructure.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: we first saw ChChes set its sights on an organization that’s long been a target of APT 10/menuPass. they followed the same pattern—exclusive packers, mutual targets, overlapping C&C infrastructure.

text: ChChes’ packer, for instance, resembled the one used in menuPass’ old PlugX samples. DNS records also showed that some of their command and control (C&C) servers and domains resolved to the same IP address, or resided in the same subnet. Are they operated by the same actors? Their commonalities make it appear so. It’s also known to happen; BlackTech’s cyberespionage campaigns are a case in point.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: some of their command and control servers and domains resided in the same subnet. their commonalities make it appear so; BlackTech cyberespionage campaigns are a case in point.

text: ChessMaster’s ChChes also resembles another backdoor, Emdivi, which first made waves in 2014. They have the same endgame. Both are second-stage payloads that use the system’s Security Identifier (SID) as encryption key so they execute only in their target’s machine. Their difference lies in complexity—ChChes hides part of the decryption key and payload in registry keys to make it harder to reverse engineer.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: ChessMaster's ChChes hides part of the decryption key and payload in registry keys to make it harder to reverse engineer.

text: But that’s just one dot in several we’ve connected. In one instance, we detected PlugX and Emdivi on the same machine. This PlugX variant connected to an APT 10/menuPass-owned domain, but the packer is similar to that used by ChChes. While it’s possible it was hit by two different campaigns, further analysis told a different story. Both were compiled on the same date, only several hours apart. We detected and acquired the samples the next day, which means both backdoors were delivered to the victim a day after they were compiled.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: plugX and Emdivi were compiled on the same date, only several hours apart. both backdoors were delivered to the victim a day after they were collected.

text: Figure 3: Overview of the overlaps in ChessMaster and APT 10’s campaigns
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: figure 3: Overview of the overlaps in ChessMaster and APT 10's campaigns. chevauchment in the campaigns of antonio et al.

text: Ultimately attacks like ChessMaster’s make pawns out of the systems, networks, devices and their users, all of which hold the organization’s crown jewels. This is why enterprises need to be steps ahead of the game: prepare, respond, restore, and learn. Plan ahead—what techniques will attackers use? How can I defend against them? Don’t just pull the plug—understand what happened to better assess and mitigate the damage. Fine-tune your response—what worked, what didn’t, and what could’ve been done better?
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: enterprises need to be steps ahead of the game: prepare, respond, restore, and learn. plan ahead—what techniques will attackers use? how can I defend against them?

text: Defense in depth plays a crucial role especially for the IT/system administrators and information security professionals that watch over them. The network, endpoints, servers, mobile devices, and web/email gateways are the bishops, knights, and rooks that underpin the enterprise’s crown jewels, which is why securing them is important. Reduce their attack surface. Keep the systems updated and regularly patched, and enforce the principle of least privilege. Employ behavior monitoring and application control. Deploy firewalls as well intrusion detection and prevention systems. Implement URL categorization, network segmentation, and data categorization.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: defense in depth plays a crucial role especially for IT/system administrators and information security professionals that watch over them. keep the systems updated and regularly patched, and enforce the principle of least privilege. Deploy firewalls as well intrusion detection and prevention systems.

text: ChessMaster’s gambit is spear-phishing, so it’s especially important to filter and safeguard the email gateway. Additionally, foster a cybersecurity-aware workforce. Seemingly benign icons or decoy documents can still swindle the victim, for instance. More importantly, develop proactive incident response and remediation strategies—threat intelligence helps enterprises prepare and mitigate attacks. Like in chess, the more you understand your enemy’s moves, the more successful you can be at thwarting them.
source: ChessMaster Makes its Move_ A Look into its Arsenal.html
summary: ChessMaster's gambit is spear-phishing, so it’s especially important to filter and safeguard the email gateway. foster a cybersecurity-aware workforce. develop proactive incident response and remediation strategies. like in chess, the more successful you can be at thwarting them.
